title: Towards Portable Shopping Histories: Using GoodRelations to Expose Ownership Information to ECommerce Sites

author: Martin Hepp, Bundeswehr University of Munich

segmentation: Now this is work done by a PhD PhD student of mine.
Last rhetorical unfortunately cannot present it by himself in here.
The general idea is how can we use good relations and schema.org and semantic web technology in general to allow people to actively expose information about the items they possess?
To shops and other applications and why this may this be useful?
Um, because we assume that recommender systems which are part of many websites recommending matching products, things you should buy, things you will likely like.
And like they often face a cold start problem.
That means the recommendations critically depend on the amount of information the site has about you.
For a big side, this works well, like Amazon, this or eBay.
This works well because you usually have left lots of traces of what you looked at and what you bought on that side.
So Amazon knows.
What you bought in the past five years, and this empowers Amazon to give you.
In theory, better recommendations than a small web shop that you've never visited before.

Now in modern web environments this is kind of mitigated by the fact that websites collect and share information, not just about actual purchases, but also about things you clicked on, things you viewed.
So you may have sometimes seen so-called retargeting functionality.
You Google, you search in one shop for power supplies for your laptop, and you go to the New York Times another user page news page and suddenly you see a banner ad.
For power supplies from the web shop that you visited just before, so they are chasing you with advertisement.
You may have experienced that before, but in general.
One core problem for many shops.
That are not Amazon and eBay on Best Buy is that they have very little information about what you own.
And what you're interested in our assumption is.
The.
That the poor performance of recommender systems in their code start scenario can be mitigated.
The performance can be improved if you empower users to actively signal information about what you own.
So a simple example is if I publicly expose that I own an Apple laptop that I drive a Volkswagen Golf that I use an Apple iPhone 5 smartphone.

And maybe a little bit of information about sports gear that I own that would already reveal a lot of signals about what I might potentially be interested and could be used by search engines to fine tune recommendations or buy shops to give mention, recommended to adapt search results, or for shops to adapt their recommendations.
For example, if I go to Amazon and search for.
Smart phone power cord.
And Amazon or any other shop knows that I drive or that I use an.
An iPhone and it can immediately suggest a matching cable, or when I look for car charger smartphone on a site and it knows what which car I drive and which smartphone I have.
It has a lot of information for targeting me more precisely.

And our idea is that the users themselves could manage this information which would minimize the lock in effect and the kind of monopolistic settings that big shops face because they know a lot about us and can make better recommendations and give a greater incentive for interacting with that big side and thus improve the chances for smaller shops on the long term.
Ow.
Our working assumption, which we cannot actually prove, is that granular item ownership information will be a very valuable signal for recommendation systems.
Why are we unable to prove that?
Because industrial recommender systems in Amazon and eBay are very advanced, finetune highly parameterized and optimized, applications that are not available for researchers.
So when we really wanted to prove which improvement this can give.
We'd have to really work with Amazon and eBay, and giving that evidence.
However, I think it is very credible to assume that.
Aside knowing information about.
As few as 10 significant objects that you use frequently that are kind of characteristic for you.
The type of computer platform you use, the type of smartphone you use, the sports gear, the kind of car you drive, and maybe a few home electronics devices.
This would empower way more.
Matching recommendations, even in a cold start scenario.
Now there are three problems that need to be tackled in order to solve that.
Purchase records are currently not exposed as structured data to the users, so when you get a receipt from Amazon.
Currently you get it as text or from any other shop.

Um, we need a standard way of representing item ownership information that can be exchanged across platforms and applications, and we need a protocol that can govern the exchange of such information between the user and the site.
Current recommender systems that use item information are typically taking purchase history information, not actual ownership information, which is something different.
So Amazon does recommendations based on what you actually bought and what you looked at.
But sometimes you buy stuff that is not for you.
For example, you buy stuff for your wife and for several weeks you get recommendations for stuff that you will only need for her next birthday or for Christmas again.
But that you probably don't.
And the items in your possession.
Are only represented to a very small degree in the purchase records with a single shop.
So for example, you don't buy your car with Amazon, at least not.
As of today, many things you buy offline or my Apple stuff, I mostly buy directly with Apple so Amazon doesn't know about that.
So even a full purchase history is incomplete.
For practical and theoretical reasons.
